awd_titl_txt: Higher Invariants of Elliptic Operators and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Manifolds are geometric objects modeling the universe. Geometry and topology of manifolds are often governed by certain natural differential equations. One of the greatest discovery in mathematics is the Fredholm index, which measures the size of solution space for such differential equations. The beauty of the Fredholm index is that it would not change under small perturbations. The famous Atiyah-Singer index theorem computes the Fredholm index of these differential equations when the manifold is compact. This theorem has numerous applications to geometry, topology, and mathematical physics. If one takes symmetries into consideration, then there is a much more refined invariant of the differential equation called the higher index. When the higher index vanishes, a new subtle higher secondary invariant naturally arises. These new invariants have powerful applications to mathematics and physics. The PI and his students plan to study these invariants and their applications. This project will contribute to US workforce development through mentoring of graduate and post-doctoral students.

The higher invariants of differential equations or operators live in K-theory of certain geometric operator algebras in the context of noncommutative geometry. It remains a major challenge to compute these higher invariants. Part of the underlying difficulty comes from the lack of understanding for the universe of groups, which plays the role of symmetries here. The PI and his students intend to devise new methods to compute these higher invariants and apply these computations to solve problems in analysis, differential geometry, topology, and mathematical physics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Geometry and topology of spaces are governed by differential equations such as  the equation associated with the Dirac operators. The Fredholm index is a numerical invariant counting the number of solutions to the differential equations. Higher index invariant is a vast generalization of the Fredholm index by taking symmetries into consideration. When the higher index vanishes, a more subtle secondary invariant naturally arises. This new invariant is called the rho invariants. These higher invariants are powerful tools in solving problems in geometry, topology, and mathematical physics.

With his collaborators, the PI has made significant progress in computing these higher invariants and successfully applied these computations to solve long standing open questions in geometry and topology. With Shmuel Weinberger and Zhizhang Xie, the PI solved a long standing conjecture the additivity of rho invariant. As an application, he proved that a large class of manifolds are non-rigid. The Novikov conjecture provides an algorithm to determine nonvanishing of higher indices of elliptic differential operators such as the Dirac operator.  With Sherry Gong and Jianchao Wu, the PI proved the Novikov conjecture for discrete subgroups of the diffeomorphism group of compact manifolds. With Jinmin Wang and Zhizhang Xie, the PI proved Gromov's cube inequality conjecture on scalar curvature. With Jinmin Wang and Zhizhang Xie, the PI developed an index theory on manifolds with polyhedral singularities to prove Gromov's dihedral rigidity conjecture on scalar curvature. With Shmuel Weinberger and Zhizhang Xie, the PI introduced a new index invariant at infinity to answer Gromov's compactness question on scalar curvature. With Rufus Willett, the PI developed a quantitative operator K-homology theory to prove the universal coefficient theorem for C*-algebras with finite complexity.  With Erik Guentner and Rufus Willett, the PI introduced a notion of dynamic complexity to give an algorithm of computing the K-groups of the crossed product C*-algebras.

The PI has been actively involved in the mentoring of PhD students and postdocs. The PI also organized several workshops (including the Oberwolfach workshop on noncommutative geometry) and several seminars (including the online ``Not only scalar curvature seminar "). The PI is also a main organizer for the math circle.
